Topic: Draw a habitat and the different living things in each
CAN: The student may attempt to draw a habitat, such as a general nature scene, without specifying if it's land or water. *(student draws generic nature scene)*
The drawing might include one or two familiar living things like a tree and a bird, but not specific to a habitat. *(student uses only familiar examples)*
CANNOT: The student is unlikely to draw a specific type of habitat accurately, such as a playground or pond. *(student doesn't differentiate habitats)*
The drawing may lack a variety of living things; for example, it may only include trees without animals or other plants. *(student lacks knowledge of habitat diversity)*
The student is unlikely able to show how living things are distributed within the habitat, such as depicting all animals huddled in one area. *(student does not recognize spatial patterns)*
The student cannot compare different habitats through the drawing, since they might not represent more than one habitat. *(student shows no comparison)*
The student is unable to explain any patterns in plant and animal diversity across different habitats through the drawing. *(no understanding of diversity patterns)*
